content: forest of firs socks by blue ammonite designs page 1 forest of firs socks www blueammonitedesigns com the forest of first socks began with a problem i had some hand-dyed yarn that was striping and i wanted to disrupt this so it wasn t so obvious after considerable research and mulling i came up with this easy slip stitch pattern that blends the row a little and adds an interesting texture that reminiscent of fir trees in a forest instructions are given for one size to make smaller or larger sizes socks i advise using smaller or larger needles you can also increase the stitch count in increments of 4 sts ie 56 or 64 sts advice is given on how to adjust the ribbing accordingly you will need 2 25mm circular needles or size required to achieve gauge for magic loop or double-pointed needles fingering yarn in your choice of colours for the socks in the main picture i used knitpicks hawthorne tonal hand painted in the colourway springfield the other pair used a double sock blank from the shepherd s hut uk on etsy yarn needle to sew in ends size and gauge 15 stitches and 21 row per 5cm 2in on 2 25mm needles as measured in stocking stitch when washed and blocked these will fit a ball of foot circumference of approximately 20cm 8in abbreviations st s stitch es k knit p purl k2tog knit two stitches together p2tog purl two stitches together s1 slip_stitch purlwise ssk slip one stitch knitwise slip another stitch knitwise knit the slipped stitches together page 2 forest of firs socks www blueammonitedesigns com main stitch pattern round 1 knit round 2 *k1 bring the yarn forward to the front of your work slip next three stitches purlwise onto your right needle bring your yarn to the back* repeat from * to * for the rest of the round round 3 knit round 4 *knit 2 insert the right-hand needle under the loose strand created in round 2 k1* repeat from * to * for the rest of the round cuff cast on 60 stitches and spread evenly across your needles i recommend the long tail cast on for elasticity but you can use any method you prefer work 15 row in two by one rib k2 p1 or your preferred ribbing stitch note that if you have cast on a different number of stitches to achieve an alternative size the two-by-one rib will not work unless that number is divisible by three there are easy ways round this if you want a 64 stitch count you could cast on 66 stitches for the ribbing then decrease by one stitch on each side in the first row of the main body of the pattern ie dropping to 64 sts do bear in mind however that the main stitch pattern for the leg and foot is worked over four stitches so your stitch count after the ribbing should be divisible by four
